nav.div: University Place School District » About UPSD » News and Information » District News » Health and Safety Update - Coronavirus

img.title: Healthcare images

br.br: Governor Inslee has issued a “Stay Home - Stay Healthy” proclamation to all Washington residents. This proclamation orders all residents, except those performing essential functions or participating in essential activities, to remain at home beginning at midnight on March 25, 2020, and continuing for two weeks until April 6, 2020.

img.p: As you know, schools are already closed at this time and many of our staff members are already working remotely from home. Essential personnel continue to report to work to support our emergency day camp and food services programs and to perform other essential functions.
In response to this proclamation, the University Place School District will take the following steps beginning on Thursday, March 26:

ol.li: All school and district offices will be closed to the public for walk-in service. Office staff will continue to work remotely and will monitor voicemail and email during normal business hours to answer questions. If you need to visit a school to pick up materials or equipment, please do so during office hours on Wednesday, March 25. After that time, and for the duration of the Governor’s order, in-person visits to school and district sites will be by appointment only.
Parents may continue to use the district office "drop box" to submit documents at any time.

School grounds and playgrounds will be closed to gatherings but open for “outdoor exercise activities” such as walking and running where social distancing measures are observed per the Governor’s proclamation.

Offices at Evergreen Primary and University Place Primary will remain staffed to support our emergency day camp program for the children of first responders and health care workers needed to care for others during this emergency.

img.p: If you need something, please do not hesitate to contact us. Contact information for district buildings and support can be found here. Voice mail and email will be checked regularly while these restrictions are in place. Offices will be closed, but we will still be available to help.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Dear UPSD and Parents Guardians:

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Earlier today, the Governor directed the closure of all schools in Pierce, King and Snohomish counties for the next six (6) weeks in an effort to contain the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The closure will begin on Monday, March 16th and continue through April 24

span.style: background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; white-space: pre-wrap; font-size: 0.6em; vertical-align: super; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: th

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Schools will operate on normal schedules on Friday, March 13th.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Please remind your students to

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: bring home essential books, materials, equipment and supplies tomorrow afternoon

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: so they will be available for use over the next several weeks. We also ask that parents consider what medications or other items need to be at home. If parents are uncomfortable sending their students to school tomorrow, this absence will be excused.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: We are committed to helping our students and parents get through this difficult time.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Breakfast and lunch will be available for all students beginning on Monday, March 16

span.style: background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; white-space: pre-wrap; font-size: 0.6em; vertical-align: super; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: th

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: at one or more schools

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: . Additional information about the time, location and procedures for these meal sites will be sent out over the weekend.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: We are particularly committed to finding ways to support parents who are health care workers or first responders and who need assistance with their school-age children during the duration of the closure

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: . If you work in one of these essential areas and need assistance for your school-age children, please email your child’s Principal and provide the name of your student, your employer, your job title and the best way to contact you. District staff will reach out to these families to develop plans for the weeks ahead.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Preparations are also underway to provide supplemental learning activities and other supports for students during the closure. We will provide ongoing communications to parents as we develop more detailed plans in the coming days.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Thank you and good night.

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Sincerely,

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

p.span: Jeff Chamberlin

span.style: font-size: 11pt; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);
-webkit-text-stroke-color: initial; font-size: 16px;

br.br:
Dear UPSD Staff and Parents:
This is the first of several communications I will be sending you over the next 24 hours.
At 2 PM today, the Governor will direct all schools in Pierce, King and Snohomish counties to suspend normal operations and close for a period of not less than six (6) weeks in an effort to contain the spread of the COVID-19 virus in our region. The closure will begin in University Place School District on Monday, March 16th and continue through April 24th.
Schools will operate on normal schedules tomorrow, March 13th. If parents are uncomfortable sending their students to school tomorrow, this absence will be excused.
We understand that this closure is very disruptive and creates many challenges for our students and their families. We are committed to helping everyone through this difficult time. Preparations are now underway to provide meals, supplemental learning activities and other support to students during the closure.
We will provide additional information to staff and parents later this evening. Thank you for your patience and understanding as we respond to this unprecedented action.
I know that this is a troubling and unsettling situation for all of us. I also know the spirit of University Place and I am certain that we will get through this challenge together.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin
Superintendent
March 10, 2020

span.style: -webkit-text-stroke-color: initial; font-size: 16px;

p.span: Dear UPSD Staff, Parents and Families:

First, I want to confirm that all schools in UPSD will remain open and on regular schedules at this time. Current guidance from both King and Pierce County Health Departments is that schools should remain open unless a student or staff member tests positive for COVID-19. We have not been informed of any such cases at this time and we have no evidence that recent confirmed cases in UP have created exposure in our schools. Parents will be notified immediately if our plans change based on new information.

We hope that school closures will not be necessary. However, parents should prepare for the possibility that one or more schools in UPSD might close temporarily. We will follow this protocol if a student or staff member in a school tests positive for COVID-19:

li.span: Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) officials will contact me directly if a staff member or student tests positive.
We will work with TPCHD to review the unique circumstances of each case and assess the exposure risk to staff and students.
If TPCHD recommends a closure, we will follow this recommendation and notify parents and staff immediately.School closures in other districts have been temporary (5 days or less).

Parents and staff will be notified if there is a confirmed case of COVID-19 in their student’s school. However, we will not share personal medical information or identifying information for anyone testing positive for the COVID-19 virus due to privacy laws and to prevent stigma.

Lastly, it is possible that unverified information or rumors will spread in the community before we make an official announcement.We will not share any information until it is first verified by the county health department.All of us can help prevent confusion and misinformation by relying on official district communications- not unverified social media- as our source of information.

p.span: I recognize that this situation is unsettling for many families and that uncertainty around school schedules is disruptive. Please know that I will continue to provide accurate and up-to-date information with parents and staff as promptly and frequently as the situation demands.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin,
Superintendent

span.style: font-size: 16px;

br.br: Dear UPSD Staff, Parents and Families:

p.span: The Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) recently posted new data about the number of COVID-19 cases in Pierce County. While the number of cases in our county remains low in comparison to King County, there are now three (3) people residing in University Place with presumptive positive test results for the virus.

strong.span: We have not been notified by the health department of any connection to staff or students in the school district as of this afternoon at 2:30 PM.

p.span: However, we are monitoring the situation closely and working with TPCHD to determine how schools and/or school activities might be impacted by this new information. Current guidance from both King and Pierce County Health Departments is to keep schools open unless a staff member or student tests positive for COVID-19.

Our district leadership team will be meeting this afternoon to discuss the next steps in our response. I will send out additional information to all UPSD staff and families tonight regarding our plans. Thank you for your patience and understanding during this ever-changing situation.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin,
Superintendent

br.br:
5:30 pm Update
Dear UPSD Staff and Families:

p.span: Shortly after my message on Friday evening, the first case of COVID-19 was announced in Pierce County. Three more presumed positive cases have been identified over the weekend. For now, there are still no known cases in University Place and no one in the school district has tested positive for the virus.

We continue to coordinate with the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) on a regular basis. I spoke directly to the TPCHD Director of Health, Dr. Anthony Chen, this afternoon about the situation in our county. We have a plan in place to respond if a student or staff member in one of our schools tests positive for COVID-19. The details of our response will depend on the unique circumstances of each case and direction from public health officials. Currently, TPCHD is recommending temporary closures of individual schools only when a student or staff member at that school tests positive. We have no such cases in UPSD at this time.

strong.span: We intend to operate all schools and UPSD sponsored activities as planned next week (March 9-13)

p.span: . Several regional activities- or activities sponsored by other organizations- have been canceled or postponed. Participants and their families have been notified of these changes by the organizer. Parents will be notified promptly of any school closures or changes to scheduled activities in the days ahead.
I will continue to provide regular updates on the regional COVID-19 outbreak and more information is posted to our website (
) to help keep parents and community members informed. Extensive information about this public health emergency is also available on the website for the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (
If you have questions or concerns about school procedures, please respond directly to this email (or call me at 253-566-5600) so I can direct you to staff who can best answer your questions.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin,
Superintendent

br.br: Dear UPSD Staff, Parents and Guardians:

p.span: Before we head home for the weekend I wanted to provide you with a short update on the regional COVID-19 outbreak. While the number of confirmed cases in King County has grown steadily through the week, there are still no confirmed cases of the virus in Pierce County or in University Place. At this time, we intend to operate schools and school activities as planned next week. Should this change, parents will be notified promptly.

We continue to monitor the situation closely and are in regular communication with health and safety partners in the region to coordinate our response. A district Emergency Response Team continues to meet on a daily basis to share information, communicate and plan. Disinfecting protocols are in place at all schools. Prevention education efforts continue across the district to encourage hand washing and to remind students to stay home if they are ill. We are monitoring staff and student attendance closely.

News and information about the COVID-19 outbreak is now dominating television and social media. It is very important that we are thinking about the emotional well-being of our children during these times in addition to their physical health. Please take a moment to review the attached guidance from national school nurse and school psychologist associations about how to talk with children about the virus.

Information and updates are available on our website (www.upsd83.org - Family Resources- Health Services). If you have questions or concerns about school procedures, please respond directly to this email (or call me at 253-566-5600) so I can direct you to staff who can best answer your questions.
I will continue to provide regular updates to parents and staff as more information becomes available.
Have a great weekend.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin, Superintendent

As predicted, more cases of the Coronavirus (or COVID-19) have been identified since my message last week. At this time, there are still no confirmed cases in University Place or in Pierce County. Public health officials now indicate that risk levels are increasing, however, and they predict that cases will appear in our county at some point. The purpose of this message is to make sure parents understand that we are monitoring this situation carefully and planning our response to protect the health of our students and staff.
We continue to work closely with the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) to shape our guidance and response. The district has taken the following steps to prepare:

li.span: A district Emergency Response Team including safety, medical and administrative team members is meeting regularly to coordinate our response
Efforts to clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces at schools and on buses have been increased substantially
Prevention education to reduce the spread of COVID-19 and other illnesses such as the flu will be provided for all students at every school this week.

p.span: Public health officials are clear that if we work together we can reduce the spread of COVID-19 and other viruses such as the flu. Here are a few things you can do to help protect yourself, your family and your community:

li.span: Read the attached infographic from CDC and share it with your family.
Keep students at home if they are sick (fever, coughing, etc.).
Keep informed. Use health department and school websites to get accurate information. Be sure to read district emails and posts carefully.

span.style: text-decoration: underline;

li.span: Reassure your students that most cases of COVID-19 are mild and do not require medical treatment.

At the present time, kids appear to be less impacted by the virus than the elderly and those with existing health conditions. Also, kids need to know that we have experience with other epidemics and have successfully reduced their spread and impact.

p.span: A small number of schools (mostly in King County) have temporarily closed over the last several days to disinfect surfaces. Nearly all of these schools have reopened or plan to reopen soon. If we are directed to close a school by the health department to help contain the spread of COVID-19 or to conduct additional cleaning/disinfecting we will follow the same procedures used for weather-related closures.

Information and updates are available on our website (www.upsd83.org - Family Resources- Health Services). If you have questions or concerns about school procedures, please respond directly to this email (or call me at 253-566-5600) so I can direct you to staff who can best answer your questions.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin, Superintendent

I am contacting you today to share information about the Coronavirus outbreak impacting several communities around the world. To start, I want to be clear that there are no known cases of the Coronavirus in University Place or in Pierce County at this time and only one (1) in all of Washington. Public health officials at the state and national levels are clear that the risk of infection is low.

We also know that the virus will likely spread. We don’t know exactly where or how quickly, but we want to be ready in case the virus impacts our school district. When it comes to contagious illness, we work closely with the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) for guidance and response. District staff recently participated in a Coronavirus webinar with public health officials and we’ve made information and links available on our website (www.upsd83.org - Family Resources- Health Services).

While we hope this virus will not impact University Place Schools, we are preparing should one or more cases appear in our area. These plans are strictly precautionary and include sharing information with key staff, gathering supplies to safely disinfect and developing contingency plans for school closures.

In the unlikely event that we need to close a school to help contain the spread of Coronavirus we will follow the same procedures used for weather-related delays. Parents will get a message and information will be posted to Flash Alert, our website and district Facebook and Twitter accounts. Decisions about how and when to make-up days will be made at a later time when we have more information.
While the current risk level is low, I want to share a few things you can do to help protect yourself, your family and your community from the Coronavirus and other illnesses:

li.span: Read the attached infographic from TPCHD and follow their guidelines.
Keep informed. Use health department and school websites to get accurate information.
Stay connected. Be sure to read district emails and posts carefully.

p.span: It is also important that we pay attention to the emotional well-being of our students as we prepare. Please make special efforts to provide reassurance to your children to help them feel safe. Students also need to understand that no one is at risk for this illness due to their race, ethnicity or nationality. It is important that we not stigmatize any group of people by blaming or associating them with the Coronavirus.

We will continue to share information about our response to the Coronavirus via email and our website. If you have questions about the virus, please contact the TPCHD. If you have questions or concerns about school procedures, please respond directly to this email (or call me at 253-566-5600) so I can direct you to staff who can best answer your questions.
Sincerely,
Jeff Chamberlin,

span.style: font-size: 10pt; -webkit-text-stroke-color: initial;

p.span: Superintendent
